Title.evidence: Methods.: This was a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study of NPC-21 for KT recipients with CMV donor-positive (D + )/recipient-negative (R − ) serostatus.

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to receive monthly 6 or 12 mg/kg NPC-21, or placebo, in a 4:1:4 ratio.

Participants.evidence: KT recipients with CMV donor-positive (D + )/recipient-negative (R − ) serostatus.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to receive monthly 6 or 12 mg/kg NPC-21, or placebo, in a 4:1:4 ratio.

Objective.evidence: In KT recipients, we assessed the efficacy and safety of fiztasovimab (NPC-21), an anti-CMV monoclonal antibody.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary efficacy endpoint was CMV infection by week 16.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to receive monthly 6 or 12 mg/kg NPC-21, or placebo, in a 4:1:4 ratio.

Blinding.evidence: This was a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Eighty-seven KT recipients were randomized; 38, 11, and 38 received 6 mg/kg of NPC-21, 12 mg/kg of NPC-21, or placebo, respectively.

Number_Analysed.evidence: CMV infections occurred in 29 of 38 (76.3%), 9 of 11 (81.8%), and 26 of 38 (68.4%) patients in the 6 mg/kg NPC-21, 12 mg/kg NPC-21, and placebo groups, respectively.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The absolute difference (95% confidence interval) was −9.1 (−23.9 to 2.8).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were observed after NPC-21 administration.
